Usage: simple [options] <input> [<output>]

This is a demo for the command 'simple', which accepts some options, an optional
<input> name and a required <output> name.

Options:
  -s, --switch       defines a (boolean) switch named 'switch'
  --next             defines a (boolean) switch named 'next'
  -n                 defines a (boolean) switch named 'n'
  -o, --opt <option> defines an option named 'option'
  --pref <prefix>    defines an option named 'prefix'
  -p:<pref>          defines an option named 'pref'

Options need not to be defined in one paragraph, multiple definitions are
allowed.

There are two special switches for simple commands, which prevent
further parameter parsing to prefer handling of 'help' and 'version' as a kind
of sub-commands. When these are defined, then you should test for these first.

More Options:
  -h, --help          "special" switch named 'help'
  -v, --version       "special" switch named 'version'
